p: An extensive and entrenched financial infrastructure is premised on the devaluation of non-western/non-industrial farming cultural practices and knowledges. This regime consummates a world-historical narrative of development built on racism and abyssal thinking: where what is made visible is at the expense of what is rendered invisible: indigenous peoples, migrant labour circuits, and farming systems that appear to belong to ‘the past’. In this vein, the 2019 US Ambassador to the FAO, Kip Tom, railed against a growing sentiment among UN member countries, and the FAO itself with its HLPE report on Agroecological and Other Innovative Approaches, that such policy recommendation ‘did not share the basic values and core assumptions on which we operate here in the United States [and is] an explicit rejection of the very idea of progress’.8 .
